channel.title: BBC News - Home

item.title: Boris Johnson warns Covid risk remains as he unveils England's winter plan
item.description: But he says the UK is better placed to tackle the disease as he outlines England's winter plan.

item.title: Covid booster vaccine rollout to begin across UK next week
item.description: Experts say a single dose of Pfizer should be offered at least six months after a second dose.

item.title: Afghanistan: Taliban leaders in bust-up at presidential palace, sources say
item.description: Taliban officials say the group's co-founder left Kabul after an argument over the interim government.

item.title: China's ambassador Zheng Zeguang banned from UK Parliament
item.description: A row erupts after Zheng Zeguang is told he is not welcome while sanctions against MPs are in place.

item.title: CJ Ujah: British Olympic 4x100m relay silver medallist's 'B' sample positive
item.description: British Olympic silver medallist CJ Ujah's 'B' sample tests positive, following his initial positive test at the Tokyo Olympics.

item.title: Parents warn of tsunami of school-anxiety cases
item.description: Cases of crippling school anxiety preventing attendance are spiralling, support groups say.

item.title: Pennies back in production as cash is hoarded during Covid
item.description: No new 1p coins were made by The Royal Mint in 2018 and 2019 but returned to production last year.

item.title: 'I learned to read again to get a new job'
item.description: New research found that low levels of literacy costs workers an extra 18 months in lost earnings.

item.title: Haiti PM Ariel Henry banned from leaving country amid murder inquiry
item.description: Charges are sought against Ariel Henry over alleged links with a suspect in the president's killing.

item.title: Apple iPhone 13 brings portrait mode for video
item.description: The portrait-mode style video setting can pull focus on its subjects automatically.

item.title: Poor housing affecting disabled children's health
item.description: A charity says many families believe unsuitable housing is damaging their children's health.

item.title: Faroe Islands: Anger over killing of 1,400 dolphins in one day
item.description: Hunting is under scrutiny after more than 1,400 dolphins were killed in one day - a reported record.

item.title: Booker Prize 2021 shortlist: 'Absorbing global stories of life and death'
item.description: Novels set in Sri Lanka and South Africa, Cardiff Bay and the outer cosmos are among the nominees.

item.title: The Papers: PM's 'plan for the worst' and 'back to panic stations'
item.description: Boris Johnson's strategy for tackling Covid during autumn and winter dominate Wednesday's front pages.

item.title: Met Gala 2021: Which celeb shone brightest on the red carpet?
item.description: After skipping last year because of coronavirus, celebrities went all out in the fashion stakes.

item.title: Great British Bake Off 2021 contestants revealed
item.description: A police detective, a retired midwife and a software developer are among this year's hopefuls.

item.title: Llandudno goat selfie warning from coastguard
item.description: Visitors have been spotted taking selfies with the goats on the cliffs.

item.title: Life at 50C: The toxic gas flares fuelling Nigeria's climate change
item.description: Joy and her family are among 2m Nigerians living within 4km of a gas flare in Nigeria's oil-rich south.

item.title: China's Covid-fuelled surfing boom
item.description: Coronavirus restrictions limiting foreign travel lead to a boom in people riding the waves in China.

item.title: The Taliban are back – will al-Qaeda follow?
item.description: Where is al-Qaeda 20 years after the 9/11 attacks - and could it re-emerge as a terror threat?

item.title: Canada federal election: A look at the key numbers driving the campaign
item.description: A visual guide to the big issues in Canada's federal election, from climate to cost of living.

item.title: Green jobs: The new generation of workers making it work for them
item.description: Science editor David Shukman on three jobs in growing green industries, and what it's like to do them

item.title: Climate change: World now sees twice as many days over 50C
item.description: BBC research finds the number of days passing 50C has doubled in the past 40 years.

item.title: Five things to take to university - and one to avoid
item.description: Brighten up your accommodation, make friends and cook nicer meals with these handy items.

item.title: Why even giant ships can't solve the shipping crisis
item.description: A shortage of vessels is hampering global trade and may lead to empty shelves before Christmas.

item.title: Russia election: Opposition crushed ahead of managed polls
item.description: Exiled or disqualified, opposition voices warn of a government stitch-up in this week’s elections.

item.title: Emma Raducanu: US Open champion on resilience, celebrations and pleasing her parents
item.description: As Emma Raducanu basks in her new-found New York fame, she explains where she found the mental strength to win a Grand Slam title.

item.title: California recall election: Fact-checking Governor Newsom and his challengers
item.description: BBC News looks at some of the claims made by Governor Newsom and his challengers on the campaign trail.

item.title: Last-gasp Young Boys stun 10-man Man Utd despite Ronaldo goal
item.description: Cristiano Ronaldo scores on his Champions League return for Manchester United but it is not enough as Young Boys strike in stoppage-time to cap a remarkable comeback win.

item.title: Lukaku gives Chelsea winning start to Champions League defence
item.description: Romelu Lukaku's header gives Chelsea a winning start to the defence of their Champions League title with victory over Zenit.

item.title: Muller haunts Barca again & Lewandowski scores twice as Bayern win
item.description: Thomas Muller and Robert Lewandowski settle a battle of the big two in Champions League Group E as Bayern Munich claim a dominant opening-game victory at Barcelona.

item.title: Bryson DeChambeau 'wrecks' hands before Ryder Cup while long drive training
item.description: Big-hitting Bryson DeChambeau says his hands are "wrecked" by training for a long drive contest while also preparing for next week's Ryder Cup.

item.title: Liverpool midfielder Elliott has surgery on ankle and could return to action this season
item.description: Liverpool midfielder Harvey Elliott has successful surgery on his injured ankle and he could return to action this season, the club says.

item.title: 'Like a motorway of ice' - Greenland swim highlights climate change
item.description: Endurance swimmer Lewis Pugh swims in Greenland, by the fastest-moving glacier in the world, to highlight the climate crisis.

item.title: Derek Carr finds Zay Jones for Las Vegas Raiders to beat Lamar Jackson and the Baltimore Ravens
item.description: Watch the Las Vegas Raiders seal a 33-27 overtime win against the Baltimore Ravens after an error-strewn conclusion to a dramatic game.

item.title: Covid rules: What's in England's 'Winter Plan'?
item.description: Lockdown rules have changed across the UK, but some restrictions remain in place.

item.title: Covid: Will I need a booster jab?
item.description: All people over 50 in the UK will be offered a single-dose booster jab of the Covid vaccine.

item.title: Which children are being vaccinated and why?
item.description: All children aged 12-15 across the UK will be offered one dose of the Pifzer vaccine.

item.title: Covid: Which countries are vaccinating children and why?
item.description: Millions of children around the world are being offered a Covid vaccine.

item.title: Flu jab 2021: Who’s eligible for a free vaccine?
item.description: This year's roll out has expanded in an attempt to shield against a double whammy of flu and Covid.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid vaccines: How fast is progress around the world?
item.description: Charts and maps tracking the progress of Covid vaccination programmes.

item.title: Covid: Will I need a jab and what will university be like this term?
item.description: Many Covid restrictions have been lifted for students going to university this term.

item.title: Covid passports: How do I get one and when will I need it?
item.description: People in Scotland will need to be fully vaccinated to go to clubs, sporting events and concerts.

item.title: Covid symptoms: What are they and how do I protect myself?
item.description: A new cough, fever and change in smell or taste are the key symptoms that mean you may have coronavirus.

item.title: What are the travel rules for Spain, Portugal, Malta and other holiday hotspots?
item.description: What you need to know about going to Portugal, Spain, Greece, France, Malta, Italy and Turkey.

item.title: Stamp duty holiday: How much do I have to pay now?
item.description: Stamp duty rules are changing in England and Northern Ireland

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The progress made in vaccinating the country's population, as more than 48 million people have received at least one dose.

item.title: Universal credit: When will the £20 increase stop?
item.description: The government has confirmed the £20 boost will end in the autumn.

item.title: 'The near-death experience that made me a top musician'
item.description: When Tony Kofi had a near-fatal accident, he had a vision of himself playing a musical instrument. It would change his life forever.

item.title: ‘Havana syndrome ’ and the mystery of the microwaves
item.description: The BBC investigates a mystery illness dubbed "Havana syndrome" that has affected American diplomats and spies.

item.title: 'I studied law in jail - now I want to change the system'
item.description: LaTonya Myers spent nine months in jail because she couldn’t afford bail - now she's helping others facing the same challenge.

item.title: Chaos and confusion: The frenzied final hours of the Afghan government
item.description: Through interviews with insiders, BBC News has pieced together an account of how Afghanistan’s government unravelled.

item.title: The hard men removing squatters in Spain
item.description: Some squatters in Spain demand cash before leaving - so eviction firms have arisen to handle the talks.
